Fields.DialogueText: Kapitein! Have you seen this report?
No, but I gather it's good news.
You've been commended for your efforts in thwarting the Rotterdam Four! Isn't that wonderful?!
They know we can't do it alone.
Happy to provide.

Fields.MenuText: If only we could have done so without any casualties.

Fields.DialogueText: That's the business of the Helleveegen. You did what you could.
*ALARM*
No rest for the wicked, huh, Kapitein?
Well, there's not going to be a Rotterdam Five.
@BATTLE
Out here all by yourself, De Ruyter?
Oh, Kapitein... Are you here to scold me for slacking?
Quite the opposite. I came to see what it is that's so distracting.
I can't shake the feeling that something is off about the Kriegsmarine kapitein who lost his life.
How so?
Why was he so set on diving into battle? He didn't make kapitein by taking gambles like that.
Educated gambles.

Fields.MenuText: You believe something ulterior was occuring?

Fields.DialogueText: Or still is.
That's what I've been musing about out here.
*ALARM*
Maybe some exercise will clear my head. Care to join me, Kapitein?
You couldn't stop me!
@BATTLE
This is all I have to report thus far, Kapitein.
Hmm. Looks like German traffic off of Dutch coasts is up. Well, so's British.
But when you look for similar correspondence between Helleveege activity and German... well. In some cases there doesn't seem to be one. The Kriegsmarine is just appearing almost randomly.
None yet. With your permission, I would be happy to look into it.
I've been poring over every chart and record of movement I could get my hands on.

Fields.MenuText: It could just be a coincidence.

Fields.DialogueText: Do you remember the last time you said that?
Better to have them and not need them, right?
Misschien. Maybe. I'm not used to keeping such an eye on my neighbors because... well, I'm not used to them keeping such an eye on us.
Well, ask around. I'd do it under color of an INPF inquiry, just to be safe.
Aye-aye!
*ALARM*
I'll start drafting some letters as soon as we get some peace and quiet.
@BATTLE
I'm not the only one who's noticed this, either. Willemsoord have been fielding complaints about the Kriegsmarine throwing their weight around.
True. And don't think I'm not also keeping an eye on the Royal Navy!
I bet.
But for the most part, their maneuvers correspond with known Helleveege traffic patterns and documented engagements. It's reasonably clear what they're up to.
Curieus.
What in particular?
Just something I keep hearing in port.
I know what you mean. Every other joker claims to have slept with a Belle these days.
What about?
Still investigating. It's something I want to be absolutely sure about. Word is that the Kriegsmarine have been running a brisk business in smuggling. Contraband, currency...
Nobody of rank yet, but at least three sailors in three separate ports swear they were the lucky ones of some captured crew.

Fields.MenuText: Is there any credence to these rumors?

Fields.DialogueText: Still searching. There's too much smoke not to look for fire.
Now you can see my concern.
You don't think...
We never did get a look at the Kriegsmarine kapitein's crew, did we? Maybe there was a reason he was so adamant about pushing through the waves and reaching his destination as soon as possible.
You think he was harboring contraband below deck?
Perhaps he was worried about getting caught and was willing to risk his life to avoid jail time. Pure speculation on my part, of course. It's unbecoming to speak ill of the dead.
Well, keep it under your hat for now. It's hard enough getting the Kriegsmarine on board as it is.
With the INPF, misschien. They're happy to patrol off the Dutch coast.
@BATTLE
No, no, not that. I thought it was just idle rumormongering, but I keep hearing similar stories.
... Even selling people to the Helleveegen.
Now you're catching on. Next thing you know we'll be finishing each other's--
That's the only thing that worries you more.
That'll do.
Morganas?
Zo, I was thinking of cooking a meal sometime for us, Kapitein.
Oh? What brought this about?
We never really had a celebration for dealing with the Rotterdam Four.
Real shame, that.
Would you be interested in trying some Dutch meals?

Fields.MenuText: Why not? It sounds like it would be rather interesting.

Fields.DialogueText: I won't let you down.
Enemy spotted, Kapitein!
All right! Let's get this show on the road!
Aye-aye, Kapitein!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Maybe... Have you ever cooked before?

Fields.DialogueText: Who hasn't?
Uh... R-right. Silly question. Of course you can!

Fields.MenuText: Could I say no and not have you despise me for it?

Fields.DialogueText: For saying no to a question?
Does something about my cooking sound inadequate?
Of course not! I guess I should try at least one dish before backing out if you feel so strongly about it.
Sounds fair to me.
Well, you're offering to do me a favor.
We'll need a few ingredients before I can make anything, Kapitein.
Is it likely to eat into our budget?
Would I be reprimanded if it did?
Then I'm sure it won't!
Then I'll keep it reasonable. Possibly.

Fields.MenuText: I never say no to a little extra spice.

Fields.DialogueText: Neither do I, Kapitein. Can't keep a good meal down.
Hmm... I'm surprised we have access to some of this stuff. Figured it was just Navy food out here.
So did I. A little bird told me that you can still get caviar out of Den Haag.
@BATTLE
Did that come out quite how you intended it?
... Perhaps not. It'll be good, trust me.
As do sailors in port.
Money talks, eh?
For everything else, there's my guns.
Can't run this whole war on rumors, you know.
Captain, ben je er klaar voor? It appears more Morganas are paying us a visit.
Then let's give them a smorgasbord!
@BATTLE
Hm. So many good choices - but what to start out with?
Preparing our meal? Have you decided what to go with yet?
Ja. My choices are all limited to what ingredients we purchased, but Dutch cooking is very versatile.
Heh. If I kept the scope so narrow then it would be too plain for both of us, ja?
You're a real sweetheart, you know that, De Ruyter?
Keep an eye out for great things to come, Kapitein.

Fields.MenuText: With a little added flair, correct?

Fields.DialogueText: It would be a shame not to add a bit of fun into our dinner, Kapitein.
What a saint, you are!
Easy there, flatterer. You can address me as you wish *after* I've made us a good dinner.
I look forward to it!

Fields.MenuText: Can you do something a little more... exotic?

Fields.DialogueText: Even if I add a modern twist to make home not so dull?
Maybe then...
I've got it handled, Kapitein. Please have faith in me to accommodate your tastes.
Do your best then. I'm counting on you.
You won't be disappointed.
That truly was a lovely meal, De Ruyter.
I'm glad you enjoyed it. It's just a shame we couldn't get that caviar after all.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe I can cook for you next time.

Fields.DialogueText: If you think you can satisfy me. My palate is quite picky, you know?

Fields.MenuText: When can we do this again?

Fields.DialogueText: Whenever we want. I might have to train the galley up to your standards!

Fields.MenuText: I'm not really a caviar person in the first place.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, you didn't have to be.
Hope I'm not interrupting, Miss De Ruyter.
Can't this wait? I'm in the middle of a meal?
Apologies, Kapitein, but the lady insisted.
Another one of your plans?
I'll have to explain later. Let's just say that there's more than one way to cook with fish.
@BATTLE
Actually, it can't.
Hm... I see...
Now you understand what I'm getting at. Order some caviar in port...
It seems your suspicions weren't that unfounded.
It's not unheard of these days to blame delays and such on the Helleveegen. But our delivery was too well defended for that.
By the Kriegsmarine - who helpfully provided an IOU.
Disgraceful. I was afraid of this.

Fields.MenuText: War is a profitable time and the Germans know that.

Fields.DialogueText: Even so... it wasn't always this way. We were brethren on the high seas once.

Fields.MenuText: Isn't it in the Germans' best interest to protect the Netherlands?

Fields.DialogueText: Can you imagine the dams bursting? They'd have another coast to deal with overnight.
Not as a matter of policy, but if the OKM know they're looking the other way.
Leave this with me, Ruyter. If it's between your countries' navies, the INPF have to put a stop to it.
That's my hope. They can't afford to let this slide.
@BATTLE
And whatever thieving schurk is plaguing Dutch trade will come scurrying.
Loudly and publicly...
Well. It wouldn't be the first time their leaders made a policy of plunder.
We'll have to move carefully, Kapitein. It could go one of two ways.
It's a matter of maritime law. Germany's offense, the Netherlands' complaint.
This may get worse before it gets better.
Or to let their thieving captains pull out.
You're out here again, De Ruyter? I tend to only find you out here in times of distress.
How could you tell?
You'd set up a canopy to keep the weather off. What's on your mind?
The future of the Netherlands hangs in the balance, Kapitein.
I'm struggling to think of ways to protect it.

Fields.MenuText: As does the rest of the world.

Fields.DialogueText: When you put it like that, I suppose my moping seems a little vain.
To think some would profit off my homeland in such a distressing time.
You have the right to be angry, or sad, or however you want to feel. Especially when you're the one who's going to take that feeling and turn it into victory.
*ALARM*
Well. If we can strike down some Helleveegen, some caviar thieves should be easy.
@BATTLE
Heh. Thanks, Kapitein. I think I needed that.
Then your country's in good hands. You're good at struggling.
We'll track them down and bring them to justice. The Morganas aren't the only scary shipgirls around.
No longer in your nest, De Ruyter? I take this to mean you're feeling chipper?
Trending that way.

Fields.MenuText: That look in your eye is a little distressing...

Fields.DialogueText: I'm quite sure I don't know what you mean.
Kapitein! Do you doubt my actions? When have I ever let you down before?
Not if you trust me with all your heart.
Okay, I'll bite.
I may have sent a few birdies out into the wild to gather information on the Kriegsmarine.
Are these metaphorical birdies, or...?
"Or." Definitely "or."
Where do you find these... "or?"
Let's just say Rotterdam brought out my people's adventuring spirit.
@BATTLE
Kapitein! I have news from the Dutch coast!
Your birdies have returned.
They have, and it seems my assumptions were correct.
How so?
The protection racket doesn't go that high, thank goodness. I'm told Raeder is going to be furious.
Looking for an easy payday.

Fields.MenuText: Is there no morality left in this world?

Fields.DialogueText: The Morganas seem to be infecting those they come into contact with with their inhumanity.
And quite a bit about German shore leave habits that's best left unmentioned.
And what do you plan on doing with this information?
Regardless of how we act, this is not sustainable. We can't keep looking over both shoulders for long.
Doesn't matter what you're told. We have to see movement on this.
Right away, or else this will just start again once enough dust kicks up.
*ALARM*
Think it over while we deal with these Morganas.
@BATTLE
Kapitein! Terrible news!
What's wrong?!
It's Amsterdam. We've got orders from the top not to comply with German seizures.
I wish it ended there.
Better safe than shaken down.
Try telling them that.
It's out of our hands now, isn't it?
I know you are an advocate of waiting and seeing, Kapitein. But, just this once-
Looks like it's on us to close it.
Kapitein?
You haven't let me down before. It's time I returned the favor.
Head for those Morganas! They should lead the way!
@BATTLE
That's good, right?
At first. Harbors up and down the coast have been interpreting it fairly liberally. We've been getting reports of everywhere from bars to brothels refusing German sailors service.
Damn. Good for international cooperation, but it leaves an opening for the Morganas.
Quite the opposite. Germany's pulled back to international waters until they can sort the corrupt ones from the rest.
You hear the statement from the Koningin today, Kapitein?
Where's she at these days?
Holding out in Den Haag.

Fields.MenuText: France has problems of its own.

Fields.DialogueText: Her words exactly.

Fields.MenuText: I don't imagine Germany would be a popular choice.

Fields.DialogueText: Not lately, but it ought to blow over if they're serious about the anti-corruption drive.
Some fool thing with the colonies. I try to ignore it.
So what did she say?
Very little... and a lot. She said nobody was in this alone and to seek shelter with friends old and new.
I thought the Morganas shelled the palace.
Objectively. France, Germany, and Britain have all offered her asylum and she isn't having it. Britain least of all.
Right there on the beach? That's insane.
They did. She packed up and moved to the Kurhaus.
"Do as I say, not as I do," eh?
I hated her for it at first, between you and me. Going to the beach where the sea monsters are.
Might as well fight for it.
But if we let the Helleveegen have them, I expect we're as good as dead anyway. I can respect wanting to go out seeing the North Sea.
... Does she call them-
Not over the radio, she doesn't.
@BATTLE
*How* many did you say--
Too many. Nobody in or out of Haarlem until they finish counting the dead.
And the Helleveegen were sighted off Callantsoog this morning. They're definitely making a play for the Waddenzee. And that means we have to consider the Afsluitdijk to be at risk.

Fields.MenuText: We have the Germans to thank for this.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja en nee, Kapitein, but I wouldn't have just let their racket go on.
At least we'll know where to find them. No chases like the Rotterdam Four.

Fields.MenuText: I guess it had to happen eventually.

Fields.DialogueText: Sometimes I hate being right.
Well, we've reached out to every ship we could find in the North Sea and the Channel. There weren't a lot of Belles we could get on short notice, but at least we don't have to go it alone.
I'm happy for the help...
@BATTLE
You haven't met Cousin Soerabaja, but she's going to be *so* jealous she missed this.
And?
Great. Losing the dike and seeing the dramatic return of the Zuiderzee would be pretty much the last thing we need.
Kapitein, do you mind if I use the radio for a short while?
Your radio. What for?
As much as I believe in the strength of our crew, I would feel more at ease if I could talk to them.
Makkelijk. I've been thinking about it all morning.

Fields.MenuText: You talk to them every day.

Fields.DialogueText: We don't keep my country from flooding every day.

Fields.MenuText: Anything I can do to help?

Fields.DialogueText: If you like. But I think this needs a more personal touch.
Very well. Have at it.
Ahem... I wanted to thank you all before we clear these witches out.
We've seen... terrible things from these Helleveegen, these Morganas, whatever you want to call them. Worst of all, we've seen them turn us against each other.
We're never weaker than when that happens - when our people look out at the dark clouds and go to war anyway. But I've never seen it happen here aboard me.
Nor will I ever. I may not be the only Dutch Belle, but I'm the only one who happens to be here when the floodwaters threaten to rise.
You're far from home. I'm alone in mine. But I don't *feel* alone. Neither should you.
That's how we win.
That's all I needed to say.
I think I needed it too.
@BATTLE
De Ruyter, what's all this traffic out here? Some of these are fishing boats!
Patriotic volunteers with extra ammunition and rations, in case things run long. They're not here for the fight.
That is a relie-- Wait a second...
Kapitein?

Fields.MenuText: Do you take me for a fool?

Fields.DialogueText: Definitely not!
I'm sure I don't have the faintest idea what you're talking about...
Make a portrait, Kapitein. It'll last longer. Perhaps I can pose with a pearl earring.
How on earth could those ships arrive at the same time as us if you've only just gotten in contact? And loaded down with shells of your caliber? And--
*Sigh* I don't regret this.
*ALARM*
Let's send the partisans home and clear out the enemy. I'll bring you up to speed.
@BATTLE
My floatplanes don't lie. They'll be in and out by the time the Helleveegen get here.
Famous last words when the Morganas could show up at any time.
Ah, how convenient! I called in some favors with some friends from the shore.
All right, here we are at Den Helder. We stop them here so we don't have to stop them in the IJsselmeer.
Wait... what are those vessels out there?
Caviar with your dinner tonight, Kapitein?
Don't have much of an appetite.
Our French and British friends are welcome to join us any time.
Truth be told, Kapitein, I've been keeping tabs not only on the Germans, but on the British and our other neighbors for some time now.
Is that so?

You know me. I like to study the enemy. I did so with the 
Helleveegen diligently before the Kriegsmarine pulled back.
Current... and potential.

Fields.MenuText: How exactly have you been keeping tabs?

Fields.DialogueText: I have my ways. My birdies have wings that span the entire ocean.
Don't look so scandalized, Kapitein. We're all at it.
When did you contact these people?
To be honest, some as soon as the first rumor landed in my lap.
Even before it was confirmed?
I predicted the breakdown of the protection racket, and I was right on the money - for better or for worse.
*ALARM*
So what was that you said about not turning on each other? Not being alone out here?
Kapitein, I never meant to-
You will deal with the Morganas and return to your quarters. That is all.
@BATTLE
Kapitein, might I have a word?
Come.
I wanted to apologize for keeping you out of the loop.
I do! I just... we've been burned by one ally. I need to know we can survive it happening again.

Fields.MenuText: And for bringing civilians into an active war zone.

Fields.DialogueText: The whole coast is a war zone, Kapitein.
I still believe it was necessary, but I'm sorry.
Look. It worked like a charm, so I can't reprimand you too harshly.
But...
But what if it hadn't? Whose fault would it have been?
... Mine.
We deal with it when it comes. And you're brilliant at seeing these things coming. But don't let them keep you from opening your heart.
Or opening it at the wrong time.
@BATTLE
And when those organized naval powers overstay their welcome?
You know I, of all people, am more or less determined to take all the help I can get. But arming off-the-books civilian fleets?
Let's worry about that later.
They don't have the training, they don't have the ability to coordinate with our allies, and - let's be honest - the odds that they shoot at each other or an ally accidentally are uncomfortably high.
Even if we could keep them knee-deep in ammunition, they can't take the place of willing assistance from organized naval powers.
Morganas incoming!
@BATTLE
More and more Morganas have been popping up recently.
They're trying to dig in on Vlieland.

Fields.MenuText: Our ship is taking a beating.

Fields.DialogueText: I won't go down yet, but it certainly smarts.
I'm starting to get a little nervous, Kapitein. I nearly lost one of my Fokkers when I was having them scout.

Fields.MenuText: At least we won't have to deal with a war against the Germans.

Fields.DialogueText: Truth be told, I almost miss them.
We've had so many battles recently, I'm not sure the hull will hold up. Let's see what repairs we can muster before making the final push.
There's a big enough port in the distance. I will set a course.
It shouldn't take long for the ship to be repaired.
In the meantime, it is nice to strecth our legs.
That it is.
While we've got the leg room for it.

Fields.MenuText: Hey, none of that. We'll be holding regattas by the end of the year.

Fields.DialogueText: Heh. I'd be happy to referee.

Fields.MenuText: I know it must be hard for you.

Fields.DialogueText: And you as well. Having to deal with my port fever can't be easy.

Fields.MenuText: We'll protect everyone, don't you worry!

Fields.DialogueText: If you say it, Kapitein, I am compelled to believe it!
The ship should be finished by now. Let's go take a look and set sail.
Shame we couldn't find any volunteer mechanics.
Thought you planned for everything.
Maybe this is part of something greater. Beyond human comprehension.
You sound like Aurora.
That's easy. You just have to drop your voice and say half of what you mean.
@BATTLE
Kapitein! Can you see?
We're being overrun here! No wonder you pulled the floatplanes back.
There is no time to lose! We cut off the Waddenzee here and now!

Fields.MenuText: This is the state the Kriegsmarine left it in?

Fields.DialogueText: Despicable, I know. But we have no time to complain!

Fields.MenuText: How can we fend off so many?

Fields.DialogueText: Reinforcements should be arriving any second. We have to trust in them!
Trust me, Kapitein! I will do the same for you!
Everyone! We will defend the coastline at all costs. Show them the Dutch don't go down without a fight!
Well said, Kapitein!
@BATTLE
There's just no end to them!
You say that, but-!

Fields.MenuText: We just have to hold out a little longer!

Fields.DialogueText: At times like these I remember why I chose-
I've got to be! There isn't-
*BOOM*
What's--?!
Our reinforcements from the North Sea and the Channel! The Royal Navy and the French came through!
But they came... They came! I can't believe it!
Now, let's show these Morganas a thing or two about teamwork!
@BATTLE
... And U-boats. You can't see them, but-
It's almost enough to make you think we stand a chance of winning this damn war, isn't it?
Keep at it! We've nearly sunk them all!
@BATTLE
Is that all of them?
I think so...
I'm still in shock...
By the skin of our teeth...
For now, at least.
I'm proud of you, De Ruyter. We couldn't have done this on our own. You put yourself out there and it won us this day.
Your words warm my heart, Kapitein. What say we warm some coffee and settle in for some repairs?
Ruyter? You're out here again? But we won the day!
Old habits.
No! How can I be? Right? Then why is my stomach doing somersaults?
I am! Don't get me wrong! But my stomach won't settle down.
My stomach won't stop rumbling. I thought coming out here might quiet it down.
What's the matter?
@BATTLE
Morganas! Let's take them out!
I placed my trust in the Neutrality Fleet - in our allies - and they aided in our victory.
Yes?
So why am I so uneasy?
Ah. Trust is a precarious thing. Putting yourself out there opens you up to being hurt.
Wouldn't it be better to just keep yourself closed off entirely, then? To avoid any kind of betrayal?
You could do that. Seems lonely, though. Trusting anyone comes with the risk of being hurt.
Even by you?
Even by me. I hope you *will* trust me when I say that I would never hurt you.
I will trust you, Kapitein. And, as time goes on, I hope to trust our allies more as well.
Is that so?
It doesn't mean I won't hedge my bets. I'm going to be writing some very long letters to certain German Belles...
